text: The square root of 3 is an irrational real number. When multiplied by itself, it is equal to the number 3. It is written as \sqrt {3} or 3^{1/2}. It is also called the principal square root of 3. It is called this to show the difference between the square root of three from the negative square root of three, which has the same property. This number is also known as Theodorus' constant, after Theodorus of Cyrene. Theodorus of Cyrene proved that this number was irrational. Since the square root of three is irrational, its decimals never end. Here is its first 65 decimal places, according to : : 97945 The fraction \frac{97}{56} (...) is an approximation of the number. Even though the denominator is only 56, it is very similar to the actual value. It differs from the correct value by less than \frac {1}{10,000}. The rounded value of is correct to within 0.01% of the actual value. The fraction \frac {716,035}{413,403} (...) is the same as the square root of three for the first twelve digits., \sin(\frac{\pi}{3}) and distribution of digits in them|journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A.|volume=37|issue=7|pages=443–447|doi=10.1073/pnas.37.7.443|pmc=1063398|pmid=16578382|doi- access=free}} == Geometry and trigonometry == The square root of 3 are the legs of an equilateral triangle that surrounds a circle with a diameter of 1. An equilateral triangle with sides lengths 2 can be cut into two equal parts by bisecting an internal angle across to make a right angle. This will also make two right triangles. The length of the right triangles' hypotenuse is 1. The length of the other sides of the right triangle are 1 and {\sqrt{3}}. Because of this, \tan{60^\circ}=\sqrt{3}, \sin{60^\circ}=\frac {\sqrt{3}}{2}, and \cos{30^\circ}=\frac {\sqrt{3}}{2}. The square root of 3 is the distance between parallel sides of a regular hexagon with sides of length 1. The square root of 3 is also in many trigonometric constants. This includes the sines of 3°, 12°, 15°, 21°, 24°, 33°, 39°, 48°, 51°, 57°, 66°, 69°, 75°, 78°, 84°, and 87°. The square root of 3 is the length of the space diagonal of a unit cube. == Other uses and occurrence == === Power engineering === In power engineering, the voltage between two phases in a three-phase system is \sqrt {3} times the line to neutral voltage. This is because any two phases are 120° apart, and two points on a circle 120 degrees apart are separated by \sqrt {3} times the radius (see geometry examples above). === Special functions === It is known that most roots of the nth derivatives of J_ u^{(n)}(x) (where n < 18 and J_ u(x) is the Bessel function of the first kind of order u) are transcendental. The only exceptions are the numbers \pm\sqrt{3}, which are the algebraic roots of both J_1^{(3)}(x) and J_0^{(4)}(x). == Related pages == * Square root of 2 == References == * == Other websites == * Theodorus' Constant at MathWorld * Kevin Brown, Archimedes and the Square Root of 3 Category:Irrational numbers Category:Mathematical constants
title: Square root of 3
